title: Traditional Units of Measurement
description: Discover the body-based and commodity-specific measurement systems used in traditional Ethiopia.

parts.title: From Hand to Foot: Body-Based Ethiopian Measurements

data.text: Ethiopian traditional measurements were body-based and commodity-specific systems used before the country adopted the metric system in 1963. These units varied based on the item being measured and the individual performing the measurement.

rows: Distance from tip of middle finger to tip of thumb (hand extended)
Distance from elbow to tip of middle finger (similar to cubit)
Distance from tip of index finger to first joint
Distance from back of heel to tip of big toe

data.text: These measurements were practical for everyday transactions in markets. Hand measurements were commonly used for market purchases of goods like butter and coffee.

Feresulla is a particularly notable unit because its value changes based on the item being measured. A feresulla of butter differs from a feresulla of honey, which differs from a feresulla of red peppers. This flexibility reflected the practical nature of traditional Ethiopian commerce, where density and consistency of goods affected how volume was standardized.

rows: Value changes based on item (butter, honey, red peppers, etc.)
Approximately 50 kilograms, depends on animal skin size

points: Reflects density and consistency of goods
Used before metric system adoption in 1963

parts.title: Scales and Loads: Traditional Weight Systems

data.text: Traditional scales, particularly steelyards, were used to measure coffee, grain, and other commodities. The more sensitive steelyards were reserved for precious metals and valuable goods, while conventional balances served general purposes.

items: Steelyards: Used to measure coffee, grain, and other commodities
Sensitive steelyards: Reserved for precious metals and valuable goods
Hand measurements: Commonly used for market purchases of butter and coffee
Load: Based on average weight carried by human porter, donkey, mule, or camel - used as unit of weight for bulk commodities like grain

data.text: A 'load' measurement would vary depending on whether it was carried by a human, donkey, mule, or camel, reflecting the practical nature of traditional Ethiopian commerce.

points: Load measurements based on transport capacity
